EXECUTIVE SUMMARY


We have adopted this Program in order to implement 40 C.F.R. 68, the federal requirements regulating Risk Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals.

This Program will help prevent the occurrence of, or minimize the consequences of, catastrophic releases by stating our policies and procedures for the management of process hazards in start-up, operation, inspection, maintenance and the other matters addressed in the federal standard.

Our Program calls for maximum employee participation and includes all elements of the employee participation provisions of the standard.  We shall, as a minimum: (1) consult with employees and their representatives on the conduct and development of the process hazard review and other elements of the risk management plan, and (2) provide to our employees and their representatives access to the process hazard review and all other information required to be developed under that standard.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies

The City of Galveston believes that preventative maintenance is the key to minimizing the potential for accidental releases.  Standard Operating Procedures (SOPs) have been reviewed and revised to enable the employees to perform their work in a safe and efficient manner.

The EPA has adopted a policy for non-responding facilities (another entity has agreed in advance to respond to the release).  This facility is a non-responding facility.  The City of Galveston Fire Department is the first responder.

This emergency response program does not include responses to incidental releases of hazardous substances, including chlorine and sulfur dioxide, where the substances can be ?adsorbed, neutralized, or otherwise controlled at the time of the release by employees in the immediate release area, or by maintenance personnel?.

The City of Galveston has taken steps to train the operators, supervisors, and maintenance crews to be knowledgeable in the emergency response program.  The t

raining includes classroom and hands on training on the proper use of emergency response equipment and procedures.  Above all, all employees know where the phone numbers of the first responders are located should a release occur.
The Airport Wastewater Treatment Plant utilizes chlorine for disinfection and sulfur dioxide for dechlorination of the treated wastewater.

The offsite consequence analysis includes a worst-case release scenario and an alternative release scenario as defined in 40 C.F.R. 68.  A dense-gas dispersion model (SLAB) was used to determine endpoint distances for both scenarios.  A dense-gas model is required since both chlorine and sulfur dioxide are heavier than air.

The City of Galveston has implemented a General Accidental Release Prevention Program to minimize releases.  This Program includes:  safety information on the covered chemicals, hazard reviews, operating and maintenance procedures, training, compliance audits, incident investigations, and emergency response procedures.

Five-year Accident History

In the last 5 years, there have not been any accidental releases from the covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage on site, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering-in-place, property damage, or environmental damage.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety

The city will address the recommendations of the process hazards assessment for all areas of the prevention program and the emergency response program.

II.  CHLORINATION PROCESS



   A.  Process Chemistry

     

          Chlorine  is used to disinfect the wastewater  effluent

       prior   to   discharging   into   the   receiving   water.

       Chlorination  capacities are generally  selected  to  meet

       the  specific  design  criteria  of  the  state  or  other

       regulatory  agencies  controlling the  receiving  body  of

       water.   In  any case, where the residual in the  effluent

       is  specified or the final number of coliform bacteria  is

       limited,  the actual amount of chlorine must be determined

       by onsite testing.

     

       The general chlorination equation is as follows:

     

               Cl2 + H2O  HOCl + H+ + Cl-



           This equilibrium is the dominant one in chlorine water

       from  vacuum chlorinators with a pH of 2 to 3, and at  the

       instant  of contact, when chlorine water is added  to  any

       water  for disinfection.  The free chlorine dominates  the

       nature   of   the  reactions.   These  often   result   in

       development  of  obnoxious  compounds  such  as   nitrogen

       trichloride, NCl3.

       

       A. Process Chemistry (Continued)



           To minimize these effects, high quality water is often

       used  as  chlorinator  feed  water  and  flash  mixing  is

       required at the point where the chlorine water is  applied

       to   prevent

the   development  of  localized   low   pH

       conditions.   In  dilute solution and at pH  levels  above

       about  4, the equilibrium shown above is displaced greatly

       to  the right, and very little chlorine exists as such  in

       solution.   The hypochlorous acid formed is  a  weak  acid

       and is very poorly dissociated at pH levels below 6.



   B.  Maximum Inventory



           Chlorine  is  supplied as a liquefied gas  under  high

       pressure  from three (3) 1-ton containers with  three  (3)

       additional 1-ton containers online in standby  mode.   The

       maximum   inventory  for  chlorine  is  ten   (10)   1-ton

       containers.   Equipment manuals, which  include  component

       specifications,  operating  parameters,  and   maintenance

       procedures, may be found in Appendix B.





   C.  Process

     

           The  chlorination system includes the chlorine supply,

       chlorinators,  and  inductors.  The chlorine  inductor  is

       the  controlling  component.   The  inductor  is  used  to

       create  a  vacuum  that is used to draw the  chlorine  gas

       from  the chlorine container through the chlorinator,  and

       into  the inductor.  The chlorinator meters the volume  of

       chlorine  solution to the inductor, the chlorine dissolves

       in water to form hypochlorous acid.



           The contact time and the chlorine residual are the two

       principal   factors   involved  in   achieving   effective

       bacterial kill.  The contact time is specified by the  EPA

       and  is a minimum of 20 minutes.  The appropriate chlorine

       residual  is monitored and controlled by residual chlorine

       testing.   The permitted limits for chlorine residual  are

       1.0  mg/l  prior  to dechlorination and 0.1  mg/l  in  the

       effluent prior to the receiving water.

I.   SULFONATION PROCESS



   A.  Process Chemistry



           The  sulfonation process is a dechlorination  step  to

       remove  the  total combined chlorine residual that  exists

       after   chlorination.   Effluent  requirements   for   the

       removal of the total combined chlorine residual, with  the

       objective  of  reducing the toxic effects  of  chlorinated

       effluents on receiving-stream biota.

Sulfur dioxide gas successfully removes free chlorine,

       monochloramine,  dichloramine, nitrogen  trichloride,  and

       poly-n-chlor compounds.  For the overall reaction  between

       sulfur  dioxide  and  chlorine, the stoichiometric  weight

       ratio  of  sulfur  dioxide  to  chlorine  is  0.9:1.    In

       practice, it has been found that about 1.0 mg/l of  sulfur

       dioxide  will  be required for the dechlorination  of  1.0

       mg/l  chlorine residual.  Because the reactions of  sulfur

       dioxide   and   chlorine   and  chloramines   are   nearly

       instantaneous, contact time is usually not  a  factor  and

       contact  chambers  are not used, but  rapid  and  positive

       mixing   at  the  point  of  application  is  an  absolute

       requirement.



           The  various reactions involved in the sulfur  dioxide

       dechlorination  process  are  shown  below.    The   first

       reaction  is  the  formation  of  sulfurous  acid  in  the

       sulfonator inductor:



           SO2 + H2O  H2SO3



        The  sulfurous  acid  reacts with  the  various  chlorine

residual species as follows:



           HOCl + H2SO3  HCl + H2SO4

           NH2Cl + H2SO3 + H2O  NH4Cl + H2SO4

           NHCl2 + 2H2SO3 + 2H2O  NH4Cl + HCl + 2H2SO4

           NCl3 + 3H2SO3 + 3H2O  NH4Cl + 2HCl + 3H2SO4



           These  equations  illustrate  that  all  the  chlorine

       species  can  be dechlorinated with SO2 .   The  equations

       also  illustrate that acids are produced which can  affect

       the  alkalinity  and  possibly  pH.   For  each  part   of

       chlorine   removed,  2.8  mg/l  alkalinity  as  CaCO3   is

       consumed.



           The stoichiometric relationship requires 0.9 parts SO2

       to  remove  1.0  part of chlorine residual.   In  practice

       this  ratio  can be can be as high as 1.05  parts  SO2  to

       each  part chlorine.  For practical purposes the reactio

ns

       described above are completed in less than 10 seconds.



   B.  Maximum Inventory



           Sulfur  dioxide is supplied as a liquefied  gas  under

       high  pressure from two (3) 1-ton containers with two  (2)

       additional 1-ton containers online in standby  mode.   The

       maximum  inventory for sulfur dioxide  is  six  (2)  1-ton

       containers  or  12,000 pounds.  Equipment  manuals,  which

       include  component  specifications, operating  parameters,

       and maintenance procedures, may be found in Appendix C.



   C.  Process



           The  sulfonation  system includes the  sulfur  dioxide

       supply,  sulfonators, and inductors.  The  sulfur  dioxide

       inductor  is  the controlling component.  The inductor  is

       used  to  create a vacuum that is used to draw the  sulfur

       dioxide gas from the sulfur dioxide container through  the

       sulfonator, and into the inductor.  The sulfonator  meters

       the  volume of sulfur dioxide to the inductor, the  sulfur

       dioxide  dissolves  in the water to form  sulfurous  acid.

       From  the  inductor, the sulfurous acid solution flows  to

       the point where it is injected into the wastewater.

   ?    The hazards associated with the chlorine and sulfur dioxide

      processes;

   ?    Opportunities for equipment malfunction or human error that

      could cause a release;

   ?     Safeguards that will control the hazards or prevent  the

      malfunction or error; and

   ?    Steps to detect or monitor releases.



   A  What-if  and  Checklist Analysis was used  to  conduct  the

   review.    The  review  team  utilized  the  What-if  Analysis

   technique  to  brainstorm the various types of accidents  that

   could  occur  within the chlorine and sulfur dioxide  systems.

   Then the team used one or more checklists to help fill in  any

   gaps that were missed.



   The What-if questions covered the following areas:



   ?    Movement of containers;

   ?    Piping from containers to header lines;

   ?    Chlorine and Sulfur Dioxide headers in the Chlorination and

   Sulfonation Rooms;

   ?    Piping from Chlorination and Sulfonation Rooms to inductors;

   and

   ?    General areas.



   The Checklists covered the following areas:



   ?    Process Safety Information;

   ?    Operating Procedures;

   ?    Training;

   ?    Incident Investigation;

   ?    Emergency Planning and Response; and

   ?    Compliance Audits.

              OPERATING AND MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES





I. OPERATING PROCEDURES



       A.   The  City  of  Galveston  developed  and  implemented

       written  standard  operating  procedures  (SOPs)  that  is

       consistent with the Process Safety Information (Section  2

       of   this   Program).   Those  procedures  provide   clear

       instructions for safely conducting activities involved  in

       the  chlorine  and sulfur dioxide systems consistent  with

       the   process   safety  information.   They  address   the

       following:



       1.  The steps for each operating phase:

           a.  Initial startup;

           b.  Normal operation;

           c.  Normal shutdown.



       2.  Operating limits:

           a.  Consequences of deviation;

           b.  Steps required to correct and/or avoid deviation;

and

           c.  Equipment.





       B.   Copies  of  the  operating  procedures  are   readily

       accessible  in  the Superintendent?s office  to  employees

       who  work  in or maintain the chlorine and sulfur  dioxide

       systems.



       C.  The  operating  procedures are reviewed  as  often  as

       necessary  to  assure that they reflect current  operating

       practice,  including changes that result from  changes  in

       process  chemicals, technology, and equipment; and changes

       to facilities.



II.    MAINTENANCE PROCEDURES



       A.   The  City  of  Galveston  developed  and  implemented

       written  maintenance procedures that are  consistent  with

       the   Process  Safety  Information  (Section  2  of   this

       Program).  Those procedures are used to maintain  the  on-

       going  mechanical  integrity of the  chlorine  and  sulfur

       dioxide process equipment.



       B.  The  City  of Galveston trained all present  employees

       and  will  train future employees involved in  maintaining

       the  on-going  mechanica

l integrity  of  the  chorine  and

       sulfur  dioxide process equipment.  To ensure  that  those

       employees  can  perform the job tasks in  a  safe  manner,

       each  employee is trained in the hazards of  the  process,

       how  to  avoid or correct unsafe conditions,  and  in  the

       procedures applicable to the employee?s job tasks.

     

       C.  The  City of Galveston has a SOP in place that ensures

       that  each  contract maintenance employee  is  trained  to

       Section A (above).



       D.  The City of Galveston performs routine inspections and

       frequency  of  the inspections and tests of  chlorine  and

       sulfur  dioxide  process  equipment  are  consistent  with

       applicable   manufacturer?s   recommendations,    industry

       standards or codes, good engineering practices, and  prior

       operating experience.

operating  and  maintenance  procedures  are  both  current   and

accurate.   The Standard Operating Procedures covered under  this

Plan may be found in Appendix E.















                            SECTION 5

                                

                            TRAINING



       A. Initial Training



           Except  as specified in Part B (below), each  employee

       presently involved in a process, and each employee  before

       working  in  a  newly assigned process, is trained  in  an

       overview  of  the process and in the operating  procedures

       as  specified in Section 4 of this Program.  The  training

       will  include emphasis on the specific safety  and  health

       hazards, procedures, and safe

practices applicable to  the

       employee's job tasks.



       B. Refresher And Supplemental Training For Operations



           Refresher  and  supplemental training is  provided  to

       each  employee  involved in operating a process  at  least

       every  three years (and more often if necessary) in  order

       to  assure  that the employee understands and  adheres  to

       the current operating procedures of the process.



       C.  Refresher  and  supplemental  training  for  emergency

       response



           Refresher  and  supplemental training is  provided  to

       each  employee involved in emergency response on an annual

       basis  (and  more often if necessary) in order  to  assure

       that  the employee understands and adheres to the  current

       emergency response procedures.



       D. Training documentation.



           The  City of Galveston?s training program ensures that

       each  such  employee has received, successfully completed,

       and  understood  such  training.   Training  documentation

       contains, as a minimum, the following information and  may

       be found in Appendix F:



       ?    The identity of the employee,

       ?    The date of training, and

       ?    The means and methods that were used in order to verify that

           the employee understood the training.



       E. Training Course



           During each training session, each student is provided

       a  handout  for  future reference.  The  handout  provides

       technical  and  regulatory  information  specific  to  the

       particular  course,  as  well  as  information   on   good

       practices.



The  training  is  conducted  using City  of  Galveston  personal

protective  equipment  (PPE), including self-contained  breathing

apparatus  (SCBA's), and when available with employees personally

assigned respirators.  This allows for students to be trained  on

the equipment they

may actually use.



Upon  successful  completion  of  the  course,  each  participant

receives  a  certificate of completion for  this  training.   The

certificate  documents successful completion of the  course  with

satisfactory  exam  and  performance  grades  during  field   and

tabletop exercises.



It  includes the employee's name and social security number,  the

duration  and  date,  the complete subject matter  that  directly

reflects the applicable requirements, and the instructor's name.

                     EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN





I.   PURPOSE AND SCOPE



     The  City  of Galveston has developed this written Emergency

     Response  Plan  for the Airport Wastewater  Treatment  Plant

     (AWWTP)  to  provide guidance for responding  to  accidental

     releases  of chlorine and/or sulfur dioxide.  The  plan  was

     developed in accordance with Title 40 of the Code of Federal

     Regulations (40 CFR), Part 68, Subpart E. Emergency response

     procedures  are necessary because accidents can occur,  even

     with  the best safety programs in place.  Emergency response

     is  to be undertaken to reduce the severity of a release and

     protect employees, emergency responders, and the public from

     harmful exposure to chlorine and/or sulfur dioxide.



     A. APPLICATION



        The  AWWTP  is  subject  to  the  Clean  Air  Act?s  Risk

        Man

agement  Program  (RMP)  regulations,  which   require

        emergency     response    actions    including     public

        notification,   emergency  health  care,  and   emergency

        training  to  respond to an offsite release  of  chlorine

        and/or   sulfur  dioxide.  The  Environmental  Protection

        Agency (EPA) risk management regulations require that  at

        a  minimum, plans must be developed for notifying offsite

        responders  and providing first aid (for facilities  that

        will  not  respond  with  its employees);  for  community

        notification   and   coordination  with   the   community

        response  plan;  for  using,  maintaining,  and   testing

        emergency  response systems and equipment;  and  employee

        training.



                1.     The Emergency Response Plan program  shall

            include the following elements:



            ?    Emergency escape procedures and emergency escape route

               assignments;

            ?    Procedures to be followed by employees who remain to operate

               critical plant operations before they evacuate;

            ?    Procedures to account for all employees after emergency

               evacuation has been completed;

            ?    Rescue and medical duties for those employees who are to

               perform them;

            ?    Preferred means of reporting fires and other emergencies;

            ?    Names and regular job titles of persons or departments who

               can be contacted for further information of duties under the

               plan;

            ?    An emergency alarm system shall be established;

            ?     The types of evacuation to be used in emergency

               circumstances shall be established in the emergency plan; and

            ?    Training of employees to assist in the safe and orderly

               emergency evacuation of employees.

The Emergency Response Plan developed herein shall

         be  coordinated  with the community  emergency  response

         plan  developed under 42 U. S. C. 11003.   Upon  request

         by  the  local  emergency planning committee  (LEPC)  or

         emergency  response  officials,  AWWTP  shall   promptly

         provide  to  the  local  emergency  response  officials,

         information  necessary for developing  and  implementing

         the community response plan.



     B.  EXEMPTIONS



            The contents of this emergency response program apply

        to  the  entire AWWTP, although it is primarily  intended

        to  address  a release of chlorine and/or sulfur  dioxide

        from   the   AWWTP?s  chlorination  and  sulfur   dioxide

        processes.   Chlorine  and sulfur dioxide  are  the  only

        regulated substances in the wastewater treatment  process

        that are present above threshold quantities.



              This  emergency response program does  not  include

        responses    to   incidental   releases   of    regulated

        substances, including chlorine and sulfur dioxide,  where

        the   substances   can  be  ?absorbed,  neutralized,   or

        otherwise  controlled  at the  time  of  the  release  by

        employees   in  the  immediate  release   area,   or   by

        maintenance personnel?.

III. REPORTING OF EMERGENCIES



     A.  PROCEDURES



              In  the event that there is a fire or a release  of

        chlorine  or  sulfur  dioxide, the person(s)  discovering

        the   fire  or  release  is  to  immediately  report  the

        incident  to the Operations Manager or person  designated

        in  his  place.  If the emergency is critical,  call  911

        before  calling the Operations Manager.   The  Operations

        Manager  will  call the Fire Department if necessary  and

        determine  if  a  reportable quantity  (RQ)  release  has

        occurred.



              Information to be reported to emergency  responders

        should include the following (upon calling 911):



        ?    Chemical(s) released,

        ?    Estimated quantity released,

        ?    Time and duration of the release,

        ?    Evacuation and/or sheltering plans, and

        ?    Name and telephone number of the person(s) to be contacted

           for further information.



IV.  EMERGENCY EVACUATION



     A.  EMERGENCY ALARM SYSTEM



              If  a  release  of  chlorine occurs,  the  chlorine

        sensors  will  sound an audible alarm  and  activate  the

        strobe  light on top of the building.  A signal  is  also

        sent  to  the main building.  THERE ARE NO OTHER  AUDIBLE

        OR  VISUAL  ALARMS AT THE PLANT THAT WILL SIGNAL  THAT  A

        CHLORINE RELEASE HAS OCCURRED.



              If  a  release of sulfur dioxide occurs, the sulfur

        dioxide  sensors will sound an audible alarm and activate

        the  strobe  light on top of the building.  A  sign

al  is

        also  sent  to  the main building.  THERE  ARE  NO  OTHER

        AUDIBLE  OR  VISUAL ALARMS AT THE PLANT THAT WILL  SIGNAL

        THAT A SULFUR DIOXIDE RELEASE HAS OCCURRED.



              A  wind  sock,  located on top of the  chlorination

        building,   indicates  wind  direction.   All   employees

        should note the wind direction and move up-wind or cross-

        wind to a release of either chlorine or sulfur dioxide.



     B. TYPES OF EVACUATION



              In the event of a release, employees will either be

        required to evacuate the plant or be sheltered in  place.

        This  will be dependent upon wind direction, severity  of

        the  release, and in what part of the plant  the  release

        has occurred.



     C.  EMERGENCY EVACUATION AND SHELTERING



              In  the  event  of  an  emergency,  the  Operations

        Manager or his designee will determine if employees  will

        need to evacuate the plant or be sheltered in place.   If

        evacuation  is necessary, employees will be  directed  to

        report to one of the four following fencelines:



        ?    North,

        ?    East,

        ?    West, or

        ?    South



              Evacuation  to  these locations will  be  dependent

        upon  wind  direction and where a release  has  occurred.

        Evacuation routes to these locations have been posted  at

        locations throughout the plant and are noted on the  site

        map  that is included with this Emergency Response  Plan.

        Employees  will  not be allowed to return  to  the  plant

        until  they have been directed to do so by the Operations

        Manager or one of his designates.



             If sheltering in place is necessary, employees will

        be directed to report to the following location:



        ?    The Operations Building



             Employees are to remain in the Operations Building

until emergency response crews have determined it is

        safe to leave.





     D.  COMMUNICATION



              Directions to either evacuate the plant or move  to

        the  designated  sheltering in  place  location  will  be

        broadcast over the two-way radio.



     E. ACCOUNTING FOR EMPLOYEES



              If evacuation from the plant or sheltering in place

        becomes  necessary, the Operations Manager  will  account

        for  employees  by making a head count from  the  plant?s

        telephone    list,   employee   attendance    list    and

        contractors/visitors sign in.



     F. CRITICAL PLANT OPERATIONS PROCEDURES



               Prior   to   evacuation  from  the  plant   and/or

        sheltering in place, the Chief Plant Operator  and  Plant

        Operator  will  each don appropriate personal  protective

        equipment  (PPE) and a self contained breathing apparatus

        (SCBA) as necessary.  The Chief Plant Operator and  Plant

        Operator will shut down systems as necessary.



              If  evacuation of the plant has been ordered, above

        personnel   will  report  to  the  designated  evacuation

        location once emergency shut-down has been completed.  If

        sheltering   in  place  has  been  ordered,   the   above

        personnel will remain in operations.



     G. OFF-SITE EMERGENCY RESPONSE



              In  the event that a release of chlorine or  sulfur

        dioxide  threatens or actually moves off-site,  the  fire

        department  or  their designee will  be  responsible  for

        communicating    and    notifying    affected    off-site

        populations about what actions to take.
